sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: 'Tis falſe.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Tis true,
But how return'd by you, thy whole life being
But one continued act of luſt, and Shipwrack
Of womens chaſtities.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: But that I know
That ſhe that dares be damn'd dares any thing,
I ſhould admire thy tempting me: but preſume not
On the power you thinke you hold o're my affections,
It will deceive you: yeeld, and preſently
Or by the inflamed blood, which thou muſt quench
Ile make a forcible entrie.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Touch me not:
You know I have a throat, — if you doe
I will cry out a rape, or ſheath this here,
Ere i'le be kept, and us'd for Julip-water
T'allay the heate which luſhious meats and wine
And not deſire hath rais'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: A deſperate devill,
My blood commands my reaſon: I muſt take
Some milder way.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I hope (deere Don) I fit you.
The night is mine, although the day was yours
You are not faſting now: this ſpeeding trick
Which I would as a principle leave to all,
That make their maintenance out of their own Indies
As I doe now; my good old mother taught me,
Daughter, quoth ſhe, conteſt not with your lover
His ſtomach being empty; let wine heat him,
And then you may command him: 'tis a ſure one:
His lookes ſhew he is coming.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: Come this needs not,
Eſpecially to me: you know how deere
I ever have eſteemed you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Loſt again.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: That any ſight of yours, hath power to change
My ſtrongeſt reſolution, and one teare
Sufficient to command a pardon from me,
For any wrong from you, which all mankinde
Should kneel in vaine for.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Pray you pardon thoſe
That need your favour, or deſire it

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Prethee.
Be better temper'd: Ile pay as a forfeit
For my raſh anger, this purſe fil'd with Gold.
Thou ſhalt have ſervants, gownes, attires, what not?
Only continue mine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: 'Twas this I fiſh'd for

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Look on me, and receive it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Well, you know
My gentle nature, and take pride t'abuſe it:
You ſee a trifle pleaſes me, we are friends;
This kiſſe, and this confirmes it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: With my ruine.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I'le have this dyamond; and this pearle.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: They are yours.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: But wil you not, when you have what you came for,
Take them from me to morrow? tis a faſhion
Your Lords of late have us'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: But Ile not follow.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: That any man at ſuch a rate as this
Should pay for his repentance.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Shall we to bed now?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Inſtantly, Sweet: yet now I think on't better
Ther's ſomething firſt that in a word or two
I muſt acquaint you with.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Can I cry ayme,
To this againſt my ſelfe? Ile break this match,
Or make it ſtronger with my bloud. Deſcends.

div.stage: Enter Alguazier, Piorato, Pachieco, Metaldi, Mendoza, Lazarillo, &c.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: I am yours,
A Don's not priviledgd here more then yourſelf,
Win her, and weare her.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: Have you a Prieſt ready?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: I have him for thee, Lad; and when I have
Married this ſcornefull whore to this poor gallant.
She wil make ſuit to me; there is a trick
To bring a high-priz'd wench upon her knees:
For you my fine neat Harpyes ſtretch your tallons
And prove your ſelves true night-Birds.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Take my word
For me and all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: If there be meat
Or any banquet ſtirring, you ſhall ſee
How ile beſtow my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: When they are drawn,
Ruſh in upon 'em: al's faire prize you light on:
I muſt away: your officer may give way
To the Knavery of his watch, but muſt not ſee it.
You all know where to finde me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: There look for us.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: My Piorato, welcome, welcome:
Faith had you not come when you did, my Lord
Had done I know not what to me.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: I am gul'd,
Firſt cheated of my Jewels, and then laugh'd at:
Sirha, what make you here?

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: A buſineſſe brings me,
More lawfull then your own,

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: How's that, you ſlave?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: He's ſuch, that would continue his a whore
Whom he would make a wife of.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: Ile trea'd upon
The face you doat on, ſtrumpet.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Keep the peace there.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: A plot upon my life too?

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Down with him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Show your old valour, and learn from a woman,
One Eagle has a world of odds againſt
A flight of Dawes, as theſe are.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: Get you off,
Ile follow inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.p: Run for more help there. Exeunt all but Ʋit. and Clara.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: Loſſe of my gold, & jewels, & the wench too
Afflicts me not ſo much, as th'having Clara
The witneſſe of my weakneſſe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: He turns from me,
And yet I may urge merit, ſince his life
Is made my ſecond gift.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: May I ne'r proſper
If I know how to thank her.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sir, your pa don
For preſſing thus beyond a Virgins bounds
Upon your privacies: and let my being
Like to a man, as you are, be th'excuſe
Of my ſolliciting that from you, which ſhall not
Be granted on my part, although deſir'd
By any other: ſir, you underſtand me,
And 'twould ſhew nobly in you, to prevent
From me a farther boldneſſe, which I muſt
Proceed in, if you prove not mercifuil,
Though with my loſſe of bluſhes, and good name.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: Madam, I know your wil, and would be thankfull
If it were poſſible I could affect
The Daughter of an enemy.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: That faire falſe one
Whom with fond dotage you have long purſu'd
Had ſuch a father: ſhe to whom you pay
Deerer for your diſhonour, then all titles
Ambitious men hunt for are worth.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: 'Tis truth.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yet, with her, as a friend you ſtill exchange
Health for diſeaſes, and to your diſgrace
Nouriſh the rivals to your preſent pleaſures,
At your own charge, uſ'd as a property
To give a ſafe protection to her luſt,
Yet ſhare in nothing but the ſhame of it.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: Grant all this ſo, to take you for a wife
Were greater hazard, for ſhould I offend you
(As tis not eaſy ſtill to pleaſe a woman)
You are of ſo great a ſpirit, that I muſt learn
To weare your petticoat, for you wil have
My breeches from me.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Rather from this houre
I here abjure all actions of a man,
And wil eſteem it happineſſe from you
To ſuffer like a woman: love, true love
Hath made a ſearch within me, and expel'd
All but my naturall ſoftneſſe, and made perfect
That which my parents care could not begin.
I wil ſhow ſtrength in nothing, but my duty,
And glad deſire to pleaſe you, and in that
Grow every day more able.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: Could this be,
What a brave race might I beget? I finde
A kind of yeelding; and no reaſon why
I ſhould hold longer out: ſhe's yong, and faire,
And chaſt for ſure, but with her leave the Devil
Durſt not attempt her: Madam, though you have
A Souldiers arme, your lips appear as if
They were a Ladies.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: They dare ſir from you
Endure the tryall.

sp.speaker: Ʋit.
sp.l: Ha: once more I pray you:
The beſt I ever taſted; and tis ſaid
I have prov'd many, 'tis not ſafe I feare
To aske the reſt now: wel, I will leave whoring
And luck herein ſend me with her: worthieſt Lady,
Ile wait upon you home, and by the way
(If ere I many, as ile not forſwear it)
Tell you, you are my wife.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Which if you do,
From me all man-kinde women, learne to woe. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Alguazier, Pachieco, Metaldi, Mendoza, Lararillo.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: A cloak? good purchaſe, and rich hangers? well,
Wee'l ſhare ten Piſtolets a man

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Yet ſtill
I am monſtrous hungry: could you not diduct
So much out of the groſſe ſome, as would purchaſe
Eight loynes of Veale, and ſome two dozen of Capons?

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: O ſtrange proportion for five.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: For five? I have
A legion in my ſtomach that have kept
Perpetuall faſt theſe ten years: for the Capons,
They are to me but as ſo many black Birds:
May I but eate once, and be ſatisfied,
Let the fates call me, when my ſhip is fraught,
And I ſhall hang in peace.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: Steale well to night,
And thou ſhalt feed to morrow; ſo now you are
Your ſelves againe, ile raiſe another watch
To free you from ſuſpition: ſet on any
You meet with boldly: Ile not be far off,
T'aſſiſt you, and protect you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: O brave officer.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Would every ward had one but ſo well given,
And we would watch for rug, in gownes of velvet.

sp.speaker: Mend.
sp.l: Stand cloſe: a prize.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Satten, and gold Lace, Lads.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Why do'ſt thou hang upon me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis ſo darke
I dare not ſee my way: for heaven ſake father
Let us go home.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: No, ev'n here wee'l leave you:
Let's run away from him, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Oh 'las.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Thou haſt made me mad: and I wil beat thee dead
Then bray the in a morter, and now mold thee
But I wil alter thee.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: 'Twill never be:
He has bin three dayes practiſing to drink,
Yet ſtill he ſips, like to a waiting woman,
And looks as he were murdring of a fart
Among wild Iriſh ſwaggerers.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: I have ſtill
Your good word, Zancho, father.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Milk-ſop coward;
No houſe of mine receives thee: I diſclam thee,
Thy mother; on her knees ſhall not entreat me
Hereafter to acknowledge thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray you ſpeak for me.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: I would; but now I cannot with mine honour.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Ther's only one courſe left, that may redeem thee,
Which is, to ſtrike the next man that you meet,
And if we chance to light upon a woman,
Take her away, and uſe her like a man,
Or I wil cut thy hamſtrings.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: This makes for us

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: What do'ſt thou do now?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, I am ſaying my prayers;
For being to undertake what you would have me,
I know I cannot live.

div.stage: Enter Lamorall, Genevora, Anaſtro, and Pages with lights.

sp.speaker: Lam
sp.l: Madam, I fear
You'l wiſh you had uſd your coach: your brothers houſe
Is yet far off.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: The better ſir: this walk
Will help digeſtion after your great ſupper,
Of which I have fed largely.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: To your task,
Or els you know what followes:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am dying:
Now Lord have mercy on me: by your favour,
Sir I muſt ſtrike you.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: For what cauſe?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I know not:
And I muſt likewiſe talke with that young Lady,
An houre in private.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: What you muſt, is doubtfull,
But I am certain ſir, I muſt beat you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Help, help.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Not ſtrik againe?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How, Alvarez?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: This for my Lord Vitell's love.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Break out,
And like true theeves, make pray on either ſide,
But ſeem to help the ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Oh my Lord,
They have beat him on his knees.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Though I want courage:
I yet have a ſons duty in me, and
Compaſſion of a fathers danger; that,
That wholy now poſſeſſes me.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: This is beyond my hope.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: So Lazarillo,
Take up all boy: well done.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: And now ſteale off
Cloſely, and cunningly.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: How? have I found you?
Why Gentlemen, are you madde, to make your ſelves
A prey to Rogues?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Would we were off.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Theeves, theeves.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Defer our own contention: and down with them.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ile make you ſure.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Now he playes the Devil.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: This place is not for me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Ile follow her
Half of my pennance is paſt ore. Exit.

div.stage: Entes Alguazier, Aſſiſtente and other Watches.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: What noyſe?
What tumult's there? keep the Kings peace I charge you.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: I am glad he's come yet.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: O, you keep good Guard
Upon the City, when men of our ranck
Are ſet upon in the ſtreetes.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: The aſſiſtance
Shall heare oſ't be aſſur'd.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And if he be
That carefull Governour he is reported,
You will ſmart for it.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: Patience, good Signiours:
Let me ſurvey the Raſcals: O, I know them,
And thank you for them: they are pillfring rogues
Of Andaluzia, that have perus'd
All Priſons in Caſtile: I dare not truſt
The dungeon with them: no, ile have them home
To my own houſe.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: We had rather go to priſon.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: Had you ſo dog-holts? yes, I know you had:
You there would uſe your cunning fingers on
The ſimple locks; you would: but ile prevent you.

sp.speaker: Lam
sp.l: My Miſtris loſt? good night. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Your Son's gon to,
What ſhould become of him?

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Come of him, what will:
Now he dares fight, I care not: i'le to bed:
Look to your priſoners Alguazier. Exit with Boba.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: Al's cleer'd:
Droop not for one diſaſter: let us hug,
And triumph in our knaveries.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: This confirmes
What was reported of him.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: 'Twas done bravely.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: I muſt a little glory in the meanes
We officers have, to play the Knaves, and ſafely:
How we breake through the toyles, pitch'd by the Law,
Yet hang up them that are far leſſe delinquents:
A ſimple ſhopkeeper's carted for a baud
For lodging (though unwittingly) a ſmock-Gamſter:
Where, with rewards, and credit I have kept
Malroda in my houſe, as in a cloyſter,
Without taint, or ſuſpition.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: But ſuppoſe
The Governour ſhould know't?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: He? good Gentleman,
Let him perplex himſelf with prying into
The meaſures in the market, and th'abuſes
The day ſtands guilty of: the pillage of the night
Is only mine, mine own feeſimple;
Which you ſhall hold from me, tennants at will,
And pay no rent for't.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Admirable Landlord.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: Now wee'l go ſearch the taverns, commit ſuch
As we finde drinking: and be drunk our ſelves
With what we take from them: theſe ſilly wretches
Whom I for forme ſake only have brought hither
Shall watch without, and guard us.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: And we wil.
See you ſaſe lodg'd, moſt worthy Alguazier,
With all of you his comrads.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: Tis the Governour.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: We are betray'd?

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: My guard there: bind them faſt:
How men in high place, and authority
Are in their lives and eſtimation wrong'd
By their ſubordinate Miniſters? yet ſuch
They cannot but imploy: wrong'd juſtice finding
Scarce one true ſervant in ten officers.
'T'xpoſtulate with you, were but to delay
Your crimes due puniſhment, which ſhall fall upon you
So ſpeedily, and ſeverely, that it ſhall
Fright others by th'example: and confirme
How ever corrupt officers may diſgrace
Themſelves, 'tis not in them to wrong their place.
Bring them away.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: Wee'l ſuffer nobly yet,
And like to Spaniſh Gallants.

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: And wee'l hang ſo.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: I have no ſtomach to it: but i'le endeavour.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Nay you are rude; pray you forbeare; your offer now
More then the breeding of a Gentleman
Can give you warrant for.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Tis but to kiſſe you,
And think not ile receive that for a favour
Which was enjoyn'd me for a pennance, Lady.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: You have met a gentle confeſſor, and for once
(So men you wil reſt ſatisfied) I vouchſafe it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Reſt ſatisfide with a kiſſe? why can a man
Deſire more from a woman? is there any
Pleaſure beyond it? may I never live
If I know what it is.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Sweet Innocence.

sp.speaker: Luc
sp.l: VVhat ſtrange new motions do I feele? my veines
Burn with an unknown fire: in every part
I ſuffer alteration: I am poyſond,
Yet languiſh with deſire againe to taſte it,
So ſweetly it works on me.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I ne'r ſaw
A lovely man, till now.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: How can this be?
She is a wom●n, as my mother is,
And her I have kiſſ'd often, and brought off
My lips unſcortch'd; yours are more lovelie, Lady,
And ſo ſhould be leſſe hurtfull: pray you vouchſafe
Your hand, to quench the heat tane from your Lip,
Perhaps that may reſtore me.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: VVillinglie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The flame increaſes: if to touch you, burne thus,
VVhat would more ſtrict embraces do? I know not,
And yet methinks to die ſo; were to aſcend
To Heaven, through Paradiſe.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I am wounded too,
Though modeſty forbids that I ſhould ſpeake
VVhat ignorance makes him bold in: why do you fix
Your eyes ſo ſtronglie on me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray you ſtand ſtill,
There is nothing els, that is worth the looking on:
I could adore you, Ladie.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Can you love mee?

sp.speaker: Luo.
sp.l: To waite on you, in your chamber, and but touch
VVhat you, by wearing it, have made divine,
Were ſuch a happineſſe. I am reſov'd,
Ile ſell my libertie to you for this glove,
And write my ſelfe your ſlave.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: On eaſier termes,
Receive it as a friend.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How! giving favour!
I'le have it with his heart.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: VVhat will you doe?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: As you are mercifull, take my life rather.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: VVill you depart with't ſo?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Do's that grieve you?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I know not: but even now you appeare valiant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Twas to preſerve my father: in his cauſe
I could be ſo again.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Not in your own? Kneel to thy rivall and thine enemy?
Away unworthy creature, I begin
To hate my ſelfe, for giving entrance to
A good opinion of thee: For thy torment,
If my poore beauty be of any power,
Mayſt thou doat on it deſperately: but never
Preſume to hope for grace, till thou recover
And weare the favour that was raviſh'd from thee.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He weares my head to then.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Poore foole, farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: My womaniſh ſoul, which hitherto hath governd
This coward fleſh, I feele departing from me;
And in me by her beauty is inſpir'd
A new, and maſculine one: inſtructing me
What's fit to doe or ſuffer; powerfull love
That haſt with loud, and yet a pleaſing thunder
Rous'd ſleeping manhood in me, thy new creature,
Perfect thy worke ſo that I may make known
Nature (though long kept back) wil have her owne.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Can it be poſſible, that in ſix ſhort houres
The ſubiect ſtill the ſame, ſo many habits
Should be remov'd? or this new Lucio, he
That yeſternight was baffeld and diſgrac'd,
And thankt the man that did it, that then kneeld
And blubberd like a woman, ſhould now dare
One terme of honour ſeeke reparation
For what he then appear'd not capable of?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Such miracles, men that dare doe injuries
Live to their ſhames to ſee, and for puniſhment
And ſcourge to their proud follies.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Prethee leave me:
Had I my Page, or foot-man here to fleſh thee,
I durſt the better heare thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This ſcorn needs not:
And offer ſuch no more.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Why ſay I ſhould,
You'l not be angry?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Indeed I think I ſhal,
Would you vouchſafe to ſhew your ſelfe a Captaine,
And lead a little further, to ſome place
That's leſſe frequented.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: He looks pale.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If not,
Make uſe of this.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: There's anger in his eyes too:
His geſture, voyce, behaviour, all new faſhion'd;
Wel, if it does endure in act the triall
Of what in ſhow it promiſes to make good,
Ʋlyſſes Cyclops, Io's transformation,
Eurydice fetcht from Hell, with all the reſt
Of Ovids Fables, ile put in your Creed;
And for proofe, all incredible things may be
Writ down that Lucio, the coward Lucio,
The womaniſh Lucio fought.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: and Lamorall,
The ſtil imployd great duelliſt Lamorall.
Took his life from him.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Twill not come to that ſure:
Methinks the onely drawing of my Sword
Should fright that confidence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: It confirmes it rather.
To make which good, know you ſtand now oppos'd
By one that is your Rivall, one that wiſhes
Your name and title greater, to raiſe his;
The wrong you did, leſſe pardonable then it is,
But your ſtrength to defend it, more then ever
It was when juſtice friended it. The Lady
For whom we now contend, Genevora
Of more deſert, (if ſuch incomparable beauty
Could ſuffer an addition) your love
To Don Vitelli multipli'd, and your hate
Aagainſt my father and his houſe increas'd;
And laſtly, that the Glove which you there wear,
To my diſhonour, (which I muſt force from you)
Were deerer to you then your life.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You'l finde
It is, and ſo ile guard it:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: All theſe meet then
With the black infamy, to be foyld by one
That's not allowd a man: to help your valour,
That falling by your hand, I may, or die,
Or win in this one ſingle oppoſition
My Miſtris, and ſuch honour as I may
Inrich my fathers Armes with.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Tis ſaid Nobly;
My life with them are at the ſtake.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: At all then. Fight.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: She's yours: this, and my life, to follow your fortune;
And give not onely back that part the looſer
Scorns to accept of —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My poor life,
Which do not leave me as a further torment,
Having diſpoild me of my Sword, mine honour,
Hope of my Ladies grace, fame, and all elſe
That made it worth the keeping.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I take back
No more from you, then what you forc'd from me;
And with a worſer title: yet think not
That Ile diſpute this, as made inſolent
By my ſucceſſe, but as one equall with you,
If ſo you wil accept me; that new courage,
Or call it fortune if you pleaſe, that is
Confer'd upon me by the onely ſight
Of fair Genevora, was not beſtow'd on me
To bloody purpoſes: nor did her command
Deprive me of the happineſſe to ſee her
But till I did redeem her favour from you;
Which onely I rejoyce in, and ſhare with you
In all you ſuffer elſe.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: This curteſie
Wounds deeper then your Sword can, or mine owne;
Pray you make uſe of either, and diſpatch me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The barbarous Turke is ſatisfied with ſpoile;
And ſhall I, being poſſeſt of what I came for,
Prove the more Infidell?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: You were better be ſo,
Then publiſh my diſgrace, as tis the cuſtome,
And which I muſt expect.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Judge better on me:
I have no tongue to trumpet mine owne praiſe
To your diſhonour: tis a baſtard courage
That ſeekes a name out that way, no true born one;
Pray you be comforted, for by all goodneſſe
But to her vertuous ſelfe, the beſt part of it,
I never wil diſcover on what termes
I came by theſe: which yet I take not from you,
But leave you in exchange of them, mine own,
With the deſire of being a friend; which if
You wil not grant me, but on further triall
Of manhood in me, ſeeke me when you pleaſe,
(And though I might refuſe it with mine honour)
Win them again, and weare them: ſo good morrow. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: I nere knew what true valour was till now;
And have gain'd more by this diſgrace, then all
The honours I have won: they made me proud,
Preſumptuous of my fortune; a meere beaſt,
Faſhion'd by them, onely to dare and doe:
Yeelding no reaſons for my wilfull actions
But what I ſtuck on my Swords point, preſuming
It was the beſt Revenew. How unequall
Wrongs wel maintain'd makes us to others, which
Ending with ſhame teach as to know our ſelves,
I wil think more on't.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I came to ſeeke you.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: And unwillingly;
You nere found me till now: your pleaſure ſir?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: That which wil pleaſe thee friend: thy vowd love to me
Shall now be put in action: means is offer'd
To uſe thy good Sword for me; that which ſtill
Thou wearſt, as if it were a part of thee.
Where is it?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Tis changd for one more fortunate:
Pray you enquire not how.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Why, I nere thought
That there was muſick int, but aſcribe
The fortune of it to the arme.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Which is grown weaker too. I am not (in a word)
Worthy your friendſhip: I am one new vanquiſh'd,
Yet ſhame to tell by whom.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: But Ile tell thee
Gainſt whom thou art to fight, and there redeeme
Thy honour loſt, if there be any ſuch:
The King, by my long ſuit, at length is pleaſ'd
That Alvarez and my ſelf, with eithers Second,
Shall end the difference between our houſes,
Which he accepts of I make choice of thee;
And where you ſpeak of a diſgrace, the means
To blot it out, by ſuch a publique triall
Of thy approved valour, wil revive
Thy ancient courage. If you imbrace it, doe;
If not, Ile ſeeke ſome other.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: As I am
You may command me.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Spoke like that true friend
That loves not onely for his private end. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena ſecunda.
div.stage: Enter Genevora with a Letter and Bobadilla.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: This from Madona Clara?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: Yes, and 't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Alvarez daughter?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: The ſame, Lady.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: She,
That ſav'd my brothers life?

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: You are ſtill in the right,
She wil'd me wait your walking forth: and knowing
How neceſſary a diſcreet wiſe man
Was in a buſineſſe of ſuch weight, ſhe pleaſ'd
To think on me: it may be in my face
Your Ladiſhip not acquainted with my wiſdome
Finds no ſuch matter: what I am, I am;
Thought's free: and think you what you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Tis ſtrange,

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.l: That I ſhould be wiſe, Madam?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: No, thou art ſo;
There's for thy paines: and prethee tell thy Lady
I wil not faile to meet her: Ile receive
Thy thanks and duty in thy preſent abſence:
Farewell, farewel, I ſay, now thou art wiſe. Exit Bob.
She writes here, ſhe hath ſomething to impart
That may concerne my brothers life; I know not,
But generall fame does give her out ſo worthy,
That I dare not ſuſpect her: yet wiſh Lucio
Were Maſter of her mind: but fie upon't;
Why do I think on him? ſee, I am puniſh'd for it,
In his unlookd for preſence: Now I muſt
Endure another tedious piece of Courtſhip,
Would make one forſweare curteſie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Gracious Madam,
The ſorrow paid for your juſt anger towards me
Ariſing from my weakneſſe, I preſume
To preſſe into your preſence, and diſpaire not
An eaſie pardon.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: He ſpeaks ſende: oh ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: And yet believe, that no deſire of mine,
Though all are too ſtrong in me, had the power
For their delight, to force me to iufringe
What you commanded, it being in your part
To leſſen your great rigour when you pleaſe,
And mine to ſuffer wirh an humble patience
What you'l impoſe upon it.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Courtly too.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Yet hath the poore, and contemn'd Lucio, Madam,
(Made able onely by his hope to ſerve you)
Recover'd what with violence, not juſtice,
Was taken from him: and here at your feet
With theſe, he could have laid the conquer'd head
Of Lamorall (tis all I ſay of him)
For rudely touching that, which as a relique
I ever would have worſhip'd, ſince twas yours.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Valiant, and every thing a Lady could
Wiſh in her ſervant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: All that's good in me,
That heavenly love, the oppoſite to baſe luſt,
Which would have all men worthy, hath created;
Which being by your beames of beauty form'd,
Cheriſh as your own creature.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I am gone
Too far now to diſſemble: riſe, or ſure
I muſt kneele with you too: let this one kiſſe
Speake the reſt for me: tis too much I doe,
And yet, if chaſtity would, I could wiſh more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: In overjoying me, you are grown ſad;
What is it Madam? by—
There's nothing that's within my nerves (and yet
Favour'd by you, I ſhould as much as man)
But when you pleaſe, now or on all occaſions
You can think of hereafter, but you may
Diſpoſe of at your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: If you breake
That oath again, you loſt me. Yet ſo wel
I love you, I ſhall never put you to't;
And yet forget it not: reſt ſatisfied
With that you have receiv'd now: there are eyes
May be upon us, till the difference
Between our friends are ended: I would not
Be ſeen ſo private with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I obey you.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: But let me heare oft from you, and remember
I am Vitellies ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.l: What's that Madam?

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Nay nothing, fare you well: who feeles loves fire,
Would ever aske to have means to deſire. Exeunt

div.head: Scena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Aſſiſtente, Sayavedra, Anaſtro, Herald, Attendants.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſ.
sp.l: Are they come in?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſ.
sp.l: Read the Proclamation,
That all the people here aſſembled may
Have ſatisfaction, what the Kings deere love,
In care of the Republique, hath ordained;
Attend with ſilence: read aloud.

body.p: FOraſmuch as our high and mighty Maſter, Philip, the potent and moſt Catholique King of Spaine, hath not onely in his own Royall perſon, been long, and often ſollicited, and grieved, with the deadly and uncurable hatred, ſprung up be|twixt the two ancient and moſt honourably diſcen|ded Houſes of theſe his two deerely and equally be|loved Subjects, Don Ferdinando de Alrarez, and Don Pedro de Vitelli: (all which in vaine his Majeſty hath often endeavoured to reconcile and qualifie:) But that alſo through the debates, quarrels, and outrages daily ariſing, falling, and flowing from theſe great heads, his publique civill Government is ſeditiouſly and barbarouſly mole|ſted and wounded, and many of his chiefe Gentry (no leſſe tender to his Royall Majeſty then the very branches of his own ſacred blood) ſpoyld, loſt, and ſubmerged, in the impious inundation and torrent of their ſtill-growing malice: It hath therefore pleaſed His ſacred Majeſty, out of His infinite af|fection to preſerve his Common-wealth, and gene|rall peace, from farther violation, (as a ſweet and heartily loving father of his people) and on the earneſt petitions of theſe Arch-enemies, to Order, and Ordaine, That they be ready, each with his wel-choſen and beloved friend, arm'd at all points like Gentlemen, in the Caſtle of St. Jago, on this preſent Munday morning betwixt eight and nine of the clocke; where (before the combatants be allowed to commence this granted Duell) This to be read aloud for the publique ſatisfaction of his Maje|ſties welbeloved Subjects.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Hark how their Drums ſpeak their inſatiate thirſt
Of blood, and ſtop their eares 'gainſt pious peace,
Who gently whiſpering, implores their friendſhip?

sp.speaker: Aſſiſ.
sp.l: Kings, nor authority can maſter fate;
Admit 'em then, and blood extinguiſh hate.

div.stage: Enter ſeverally, Alvarez and Lucio, Vitelli and Lamora.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Stay, yet be pleaſd to think, and let not daring
Wherein men nowadaies exceed even beaſts,
And think themſelves not men elſe, ſo tranſport you
Beyond the bounds of Chriſtianity:
Lord Alvarez, Vitelli, Gentlemen,
No Town in Spaine, from our Metropolis
Unto the rudeſt hovell, but is great
With your aſſured valours daily proofes:
Oh wil you then, for a ſuperfluous fame,
A ſound of honour, which in theſe times, all
Like heretiques profeſſe (with obſtinacy)
But moſt erroneouſly, venture your ſoules,
Tis a hard taſque, thorough a Sea of blood
To ſaile, and land at Heaven?

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I hope not
If juſtice be my Pilot: but my Lord,
You know, if argument, or time, or love,
Could reconcile, long ſince we had ſhook hands;
I dare proteſt, your breath cooles not a veine
In any one of us, but blowes the fire
Which nought but blood reciprocall can quench.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Vitelli, thou ſayſt bravely, and ſayſt right,
And I wil kill thee for't, I love thee ſo.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Ha, ha, old man: upon thy death Ile build
A ſtory (with this arme) for thy old wife
To tell thy daughter Clara ſeven yeeres hence
As ſhe ſits weeping by a wintet fire,
How ſuch a time Vitelli ſlew her husband
With the ſame Sword his daughter favour'd him,
And lives, and weares it yet: Come Lamorall,
Redeeme thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Shall on this Sword receive thy bleeding heart,
For my preſented hat, laid at her feet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thou talkſt wel Lamorall, but tis thy head
That I wil carry to her to thy hat:
Fie father, I do coole too much.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Oh boy:
Thy fathers true ſonne:
Beat Drums,—and ſo good morrow to your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Brave reſolutions.

sp.speaker: Anaſt.
sp.l: Brave, and Spaniſh right.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: How the devill
Got theſe Cats into th' gutter? my puſſe too?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Heare us.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: We muſt be heard.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: We will be heard
Vitelli; looke, ſee Clara on her knees
Imploring thy compaſſion: Heaven, how ſternly
They dart their emulous eyes, as if each ſcorn'd
To be behind the other in a look!
Mother, death needs no Sword here: oh my ſiſter
(Fate faine would have it ſo) perſwade, entreat,
A Ladies teares are ſilent Orators
(Or ſhould be ſo at leaſt) to move beyond
The honeſt tongu'd-Rethoritian:
Why will you fight? why do's an uncles death
Twentie yeare old, exceed your love to me
But twentie daies? whoſe forc'd cauſe, and faire manner
You could not underſtand, onely have heard.
Cuſtome, that wrought ſo cunningly on nature
In me, that I forgot my ſex, and knew not
Whether my body femall were, or male,
You did unweave, and had the power to charme
A new creation in me, made me feare
To think on thoſe deeds I did perpetrate,
How little power though you allow to me
That cannot with my ſighes, my teares, my prayers
Move you from your own loſſe, if you ſhoule gaine.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: I muſt forget you Clara, 'till I have
Redeem'd my uncles blood, that brands my face
Like a peſtiferous Carbuncle: I am blinde
To what you doe: deafe to your cries: and Marble
To all impulſive exorations.
When on this point, I have pearch'd thy fathers ſoule,
Ile tender thee this bloody reeking hand
Drawne forth the bowels of that murtherer:
If thou canſt love me then, i'le marry thee,
And for thy father loſt, get thee a Sonne;
On no condition elſe.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: Moſt barbarous.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Savage.

sp.speaker: Anaſt.
sp.l: Irreligious.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Oh Lucio!
Be thou more mercifull: thou bear'ſt fewer yeers,
Art lately wean'd from ſoft effeminacy,
A maidens manners, and a maidens heart
Are neighbours ſtill to thee: be then more milde,
Proceed not to this combat; bee'ſt thou deſperate
Of thine owne life? yet (deereſt) pitty mine
Thy valour's not thine owne, I gave it thee,
Theſe eyes begot it, this tongue bred it up,
This breaſt would lodge it: doe not uſe my gifts
To mine own ruine: I have made thee rich,
Be not ſo thankleſſe, to undoe me for't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Miſtreſſe, you know I doe not weare a vaine.
I would not rip for you, to doe you ſervice:
Life's but a word, a ſhadow, a melting dreame,
Compar'd to eſſentiall, and eternall honour.
Why, would you have me value it beyond
Your brother: if I firſt caſt down my ſword
May all my body here, be made one wound,
And yet my ſoule not finde heaven thorough it.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: You would be catter-walling too, but peace,
Goe, get you home, and provide dinner for
Your Sonne, and me: we'l be exceeding merry:
Oh Lucio, I will have thee cock of all
The proud Vitellies that doe live in Sprine:
Fie, we ſhall take cold: hunch:— I am hoarſe
Already.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: How your Siſter whets my ſpleene!
I could eate Lucio now:

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Lamorall: you have often ſworne
You'ld be commanded by me.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Vitelli, Brother,
Ev'n for your Fathers ſoule, your uncles blood,
As you doe love my life: but laſt, and moſt
As you reſpect your own Honour, and Fame,
Throw downe your ſword; he is moſt valiant
That herein yeelds firſt.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Peace, you foole.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why Lucio,
Doe thou begin; 'tis no diſparagement:
He's elder, and thy better, and thy valour
Is in his infancy.

sp.speaker: Gen
sp.l: Or pay it me,
To whom thou ow'ſt it: Oh, that conſtant time
Would but goe back a week, then Lucio
Thou would'ſt not dare to fight.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Lucio, thy Mother,
Thy Mother beggs it: throw thy ſword down firſt.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Ile throw his head downe after then.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: You have often ſwore you'ld be commanded by me.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Never to this: your ſpight, and ſcorn Genevora,
H'as loſt all power in me:

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Your hearing for ſix words.

sp.speaker: Aſſ.
sp.l: Say. An. Strange obſtinacy!

sp.speaker: Al. Vit. Lu. Lam.
sp.l: We'l ſtay no longer.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Then by thy oath Vitelli,
Thy dreadfull oath, thou wouldſt returne that ſword
When I ſhould aske it, give it to me, now,
This inſtant I require it.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: By thy vow,
As dreadfull, Lucio, to obey my will
In any one thing I would watch to challenge,
I charge thee not to ſtrike a ſtroake: now he
Of our two brothers that loves perjurie
Beſt, and dares firſt be damn'd, infringe his vow.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Excellent Ladies.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Piſh you tyrannize.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: We did equivocate.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: On.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Then Lucio,
So well I love my husband, for he is ſo,
(wanting but ceremony) that I pray
His vengefull ſword may fall upon thy head
ſuccesfully for falſe-hood to his Siſter.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I likewiſe pray (Vitelli) Lucio's ſword
(who equally is my husband, as thou hers)
May finde thy falſe heart, that durſt gage thy faith,
And durſt not keepe it.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: Are you men, or ſtone.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Men, and we'l prove it with our ſwords:

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Your hearing for ſix words, and we have done,
Zancho come forth—we'l fight our challenge too: Enter
Now ſpeake your reſolutions. Bobadilla with two ſwords and a Piſtoll.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: Theſe they are,
The firſt blow given betwixt you, ſheathes theſe ſwords
In one anothers boſomes.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: And rogue, looke
You at that inſtant doe diſcharge that Piſtoll
Into my breaſt: if you ſtart back, or quake,
Ile ſtick you like a Pigge.

sp.speaker: A●v.
sp.l: — hold: you are mad.

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: This we ſaid: and by our hope of bliffe
This we will doe: ſpeake your intents.

sp.speaker: Cla. Gen.
sp.l: Strike.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Shoot.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Vit. Lu. La. Hold, hold: all friends.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: Come downe.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Theſe devilliſh women
Can make men friends and enemies when they liſt.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: A gallant undertaking and a happie;
Why this is noble in you: and will be
A well comer preſent to our Maſter Philip
Then the returne from his Indies. Enter Clara, Genevora Eugenia and Bobadilla.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Father your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Take her: if he bring not
Betwixt you, boyes that will finde out new worlds,
And win 'em too I'm a falſe Prophet.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Brother.
There is a Siſter: long divided ſtreames
Mix now at length, by fate.

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I am not regarded: I was the carefull Steward that provided theſe Inſtruments of peace, I put the longeſt weapon in your Siſters hand, (my Lord) becauſe ſhe was the ſhorteſt Lady: For likely the ſhorteſt Ladies, love the longeſt—men: And for mine own part, I could have diſcharged it: my Piſtoll is no ordinary Piſtoll, it has two ramming Bullets; but thought I, why ſhould I ſhoot my two bullets into my old Lady? if they had gon, I would not have ſtaid long after: I would ev'n have died too, bravely y'faith, like a Roman-Steward: hung my ſelfe in mine owne Chaine; and there had been a ſtory of Bobadilla, Spindola, Zancho, for after ages to lament: hum: I perceive I am not onely not regarded, but alſo not rewarded.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Prethee peace: 'ſhalt have a new chaine, next
Saint Iaques day, or this new gilt:

sp.speaker: Bob.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied: let vertue have her due: And yet i am melancholy upon this atonement: pray heaven the State rue it not: I would my Lord Vitellies Steward, and I could meet: they ſhould finde it ſhould coſt 'em a little more to make us friends: well, I will forſweare wine, and women for a yeere: and then I will be drunk to morrow, and runne a whoring like a dogge with a broken bottle at's taile; then will I repent next day, and forſweare 'em againe more vehemently: be for-ſworne next day againe, and repent my repentance: for thus a melancholy Gentleman doth, and ought to live.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: Nay, you ſhall dine with me: and afterward
Ile with 'ye to the King: But firſt, I will
Diſpatch the Caſtles buſineſſe, that this day
May be compleat. Bring forth the malefactors. Enter Al|guazier, Pachieco, Metaldi, Mendoza, Lazaril. Piorato. Malroda, & Guard.
You Alguazier, the Ringleader of theſe
Poore fellowes, are degraded from your office,
You muſt reſtore all ſtolne goods you receiv'd,
And watch a twelve moneth without any pay:
This, if you faile of, (all your goods confiſcate)
You are to be whipt, and ſent into the Gallies.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.l: I like all, but reſtoring that Catholique doctrine
I doe diſlike: Learn all ye officers
By this to live uprightly (if you can) Exit.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: You Cobler, to tranſlate your manners new,
Are doom'd to th' Cloyſter of the Mendicants,
With this your brother; botcher there, for nothing
To cobble, and heel hoſe for the poor Friers,
Till they allow your pennance for ſufficient,
And your amendment; then you ſhall be freed,
And may ſet up againe,

sp.speaker: Pach.
sp.l: Mendoza, come.
Our ſoules have trod awry, in all mens ſight,
We'l underlay 'em, till they goe upright. Exit. Pach. & Mend.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: Smith, in thoſe ſhackles you for your hard heart
Muſt lye by th'heeles a yeer.

sp.speaker: Met.
sp.l: I have ſhod your horſe, my Lord. Exit.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: Away: for you, my hungry white-loaf'd face,
You muſt to th' Gallies, where you ſhall be ſure
To have no more bits, then you ſhall have blowes.

sp.speaker: Laz.
sp.l: Well, though herrings want, I ſhall have rowes.

sp.speaker: Aſſiſt.
sp.l: Signior, you have prevented us, and puniſh'd
Your ſelfe ſevereller then we would have done.
You have married a whore: may ſhe prove honeſt.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: 'Tis better my Lord, then to marry an honeſt wo|man
That may prove a whore.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: 'Tis a hanſome wench: and thou canſt keepe her tame:
Ile ſend you what I promis'd.

sp.speaker: Pio.
sp.l: Ioy to your Lordſhips.

sp.speaker: Alv.
sp.l: Here may all Ladies learne, to make of foes
The perfect'ſt friends: and not the perfect'ſt foes
Of deereſt friends, as ſome doe now a dayes.

sp.speaker: Vit.
sp.l: Behold the power of love, to nature loſt
By cuſtome irrecoverably, paſt the hope
Of friends reſtoring, love hath here retriv'd
To her own habit, made her bluſh to ſee
Her ſo long monſtrous metamorphoſes,
May ſtrange affaires never have worſe ſucceſſe. Exeunt.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: OVr Auhor feares there are ſome Rebell hearts,
Whoſe dulneſſe doth oppoſe loves peircing darts;
Such will be apt to ſay there wanted wit,
The language low, very few ſcaenes are writ
With ſpirit and life; ſuch odde things as theſe
He cares not for, nor ever meanes to pleaſe;
For if your ſelves a Miſtreſſe or loves friends,
Are lik't with this ſmooth Play he hath his ends.

div.head: A PROLOGUE. At the reviving of this Play.
div.l: STatues and Pictures challenge price and fame;
If they can juſtly boaſt, and prove they came
From Phidias or Apelles. None deny,
Poets and Painters hold a ſympathy;
Yet their workes may decay and loſe their grace,
Receiving blemiſh in their limbs or face.
When the minds art has this preheminence,
She ſtill retaineth her firſt excellence.
Then why ſhould not this deere peece be eſteem'd
Child to the richeſt fancies that ere teem'd?
When not their meaneſt off-ſpring, that came forth,
But bore the image of their fathers worth.
Beaumonts, and Fletchers, whoſe deſert outwayes
The beſt applauſe, and their leaſt ſprig of Bayes
Is worthy Phaebus; and who comes to gather
Their fruits of wit, he ſhall not rob the treaſure.
Nor can you ever ſurfeit of the plenty,
Nor can you call them rare, though they be dainty:
The more you take, the more you do them right,
And wee will thanke you for your own delight.
